properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall on tap Thursday through Friday. Snow is expected to move into areas near Lake Superior Thursday morning and continue into Friday. Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm are possible. The heaviest snowfall is most likely from Thursday afternoon until Friday morning. Travel conditions along Highway 17 between Nipigon and Wawa will likely become hazardous due to accumulating snow and very low visibility. Motorists should consider changing travel plans accordingly. Snowfall warnings may be issued as this event draws closer. At this point, it appears that the town of Wawa may receive lesser amounts than areas farther west. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-04T13:01:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-03T21:02:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3352794811.2021
Area: Nipigon - Rossport, Marathon - Schreiber, White River - Dubreuilville, Wawa - Pukaskwa Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Boil Water Order Alert Is Being Issued By City Of Estevan.
properties.Summary:
Description: The Sask Health Authority, Water Security Agency and the City of Estevan have announced that effective immediately, an Emergency Boil Water Order has been issued for the South Side of the City of Estevan. This area affected is south of the railway tracks.
Expires: 2021-02-08T18:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK City of Estevan, Town of Lampman, RM of Browning, 2021-02-03T18:11:21-06:00, 05727803-1958-CFB9-476D-44ACA7490AA3
Area: City of Estevan south side of tracks
properties.Author: SK City of Estevan, Town of Lampman, RM of Browning

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High southerly winds are gusting to near 90 km/h this morning. Winds will gradually diminish during the morning. High southerly winds will reach near 100 km/h during the day on Friday. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-05T01:21:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-04T09:22:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2572568115.2021
Area: Salluit
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. Snow will begin this morning and continue through Friday before tapering to light flurries Friday night. Strong northwesterly winds gusting up to 50 km/h will develop on Friday resulting in localized areas of blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-05T02:12:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-04T10:13:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1691145022.2021

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extremely cold wind chills between -55 and -60 are expected again tonight in several Arctic communities. These extremely cold conditions may persist into the early part of the weekend in some communities. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Snow is occurring behind a low pressure system now in Ontario. Near the Ontario border, east of Lake Winnipeg, snowfall amounts are likely to exceed 10 cm before tapering off today. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. An upper disturbance moving through the area overnight will produce 10 to 15 cm of snow across the Williston area near and south of Mackenzie. Heavy snow will end mid-morning on Thursday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northerly 60 km/h. Locations: Hopedale and vicinity. Time span: overnight tonight until Thursday evening. Remarks: Fresh snowfall will combine with strong northerly winds overnight tonight and Thursday to give poor visibilities in snow and blowing snow. Conditions will improve Thursday evening as the winds ease. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-04T18:42:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-04T02:43:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2669058142.2021
Area: Hopedale and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall with blowing snow is expected. Locations: Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River, Cartwright to Black Tickle, Rigolet and vicinity, and Postville - Makkovik. Time span: continuing through tonight. Total snowfall: 25 to 35 cm except 15 to 25 cm from Postville - Makkovik to Rigolet. Maximum wind gusts: easterly to northeasterly 60 to 70 km/h. Remarks: Heavy snow and strong east to northeasterly winds will give widespread blowing snow and reduced visibilities tonight. Although periods of snow will continue on Thursday, the rates will be lower and the winds will ease so the overall conditions will improve. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-04T13:59:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-04T02:43:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1949630226.2021
Area: Cartwright to Black Tickle, Rigolet and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik, Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intense band of flurries is tracking eastwards along a cold front across southern Manitoba this evening. Periods of brief but intense snowfall are expected. Visibilities will be rapidly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow. Local snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 centimeters are forecast to fall tonight under this band of snow. The band of snow currently stretches from Portage la Prairie southwards to the U.S. border and northwards to the central Interlake. The snow will enter the Red River Valley this evening, reaching the Winnipeg area between 6 and 8 pm and taper off overnight. The cold front will usher in a period of frigid temperatures that will persist well into next week. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-04T14:15:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-04T01:08:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2332306452.2021
Area: Lake Winnipeg - south basin, Lake Manitoba
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for Thursday into Friday. Snow is expected to move into the area Thursday morning and continue into Friday. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected. Poor winter driving conditions especially on Highway 17 are expected due to accumulating snow and low visibility. Motorists should consider changing travel plans accordingly. At this point it appears the heaviest snowfall amounts will remain confined to areas immediately along the shore of Lake Superior where snowfall warnings are in effect. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-04T20:19:56-00:00

Area: White River - Dubreuilville

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. An increasing gradient between a trough over Hudson Bay and a ridge over the NWT will create blizzard conditions for Coral Harbour beginning overnight tonight and ending late Friday morning. Northeasterly winds of 50 gusting 70 km/h along with some falling snow are expected to develop overnight. The winds will ease during the day on Friday. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-05T01:26:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-04T09:27:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1297979597.2021
Area: Coral Harbour
properties.Author: Environment Canada
